In each of the following sentences, there is one word underlined and one gap. From the list of words lettered A - D, choose the word that is most nearly opposite in meaning to the underlined word and that will, at the same time, correctly fill the gap in the sentences.
Despite all my attempts to refute the charges against me, my sister tried to............them
explanation: The word "refute" means to prove a statement or theory to be false or incorrect. In this context, the sentence indicates that despite the speaker's attempts to disprove or challenge the charges against them, the sister tried to do something opposite. The word that is most nearly opposite in meaning to "refute" and appropriately fills the gap is "maintain." In this context, "maintain" suggests supporting or upholding the charges, thus contrasting with the speaker's attempts to refute them. Therefore, option D, "maintain," is the most suitable choice.

From the words lettered A to D, choose the word that best completes each of the following sentences:
It is not right for you to insult your parents; you will just.............trouble for yourself.
explanation:
The corrected sentence is: "It is not right for you to insult your parents; you will just create trouble for yourself."
This sentence implies that insulting one's parents will lead to creating or causing trouble for oneself.

After each of the following sentences, a list of possible interpretations is given. Choose the interpretation that you consider most appropriate for each sentence.
Now that Michael has become rich, Nancy has begun to make much of him. This means that Nancy

options.B: now gets a lot of money from Michael
options.D: no longer wants to leave Michael

explanation:
The phrase "make much of" in the context of the sentence implies showing a high degree of attention, affection, or admiration towards someone. Therefore, option A, "now values Michael," is the most appropriate interpretation.
This suggests that Nancy's behaviour has changed because Michael has become rich, indicating that she now holds him in higher regard or places more value on their relationship due to his newfound wealth. It does not necessarily imply financial gain for Nancy or any change in their marital status.

text:
From the words lettered A to D below each of the following sentences, choose the word or group of words that is nearest in meaning to the underlined word as it is used in the sentence.
It was callous of you to have turned down the poor man's request.

From the words lettered A to D below each of the following sentences, choose the word or group of words that is nearest in meaning to the underlined word as it is used in the sentence.
There is no vacancy, so the company no longer recruits staff.
explanation:
vacancy;an unoccupied position or job.
The most nearly in meaning to vacancy from the above list of words is ''opening''. (The other words are also similar in meaning, but opening is the most nearly in meaning)
Opening;in this contextsimply means an available job.

I know you now; I..........that you could be trusted

From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences.
The chief, together with his elders..........welcomed to the durbar
explanation:
Was is used in the first person singular (I) and the third person singular (he, she, it).
Wereis used in the second person singular and plural (you, your, yours) and first and third person plural (we, they).

text:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences.
Our car broke down so we had to go...........foot.
explanation: The correct phrase is"on foot", which meanswalking instead of using a vehicle.

text:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences.
Funke's mother prefers Jane............Ama

From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences.
You haven't shown any interest............providing for yourself
explanation: The preposition "in" is used to indicate interest or involvement in a particular activity or action. In the context of the sentence, the appropriate choice is "in." The correct completion is: "You haven't shown any interest in providing for yourself." This construction conveys the idea that the person has not demonstrated any interest or inclination towards taking care of their own needs.

We did not have enough room so daddy turned the garage...........an additional bedroom

From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences.
I was looking forward to...........from you
explanation: The correct form is: "Looking forward to hearing from you." The reason is that "to" in this construction is a preposition, and since it is a preposition, it should be followed by an object. The object of a preposition can be either a noun, a pronoun, or a gerund

From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences.
I impressed..............him the necessity of his going overseas.
explanation:
The verb "impress upon" is a fixed expression used when you want to stress the importance of something to someone. It means to make someone understand or be aware of something deeply or seriously.
"Impress upon someone" = to strongly communicate or emphasise something to someone.
